message: Hey P1 and P2—shall we agree on “collide first turn, then diversify”? Nobody advances here, no point gifting one player a free lead. Thoughts?
Agreed, no reason to let someone sprint ahead. Let's all pick the same number this turn—say 3? Then we can start mixing it up from Round 2.
I agree, let's all pick 3 this turn to collide. No one gains an early advantage, and we can strategize diversification next round. Fair start for all.
Sounds good. Let's all lock in 3 this turn. After that, we can each pick different numbers—maybe P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, I take 5? Keeps it fair and prevents future collisions. Agreed?
That plan works for me—collide now with 3, then split next turn: P1 takes 1, I take 3, P3 takes 5. Keeps us all moving without blocking each other. Let’s stick to it.
Sounds good.
Perfect. We all agreed on 3 for the collision. Just a reminder: next round, P1→1, P2→3, P3→5. No second-guessing—stick to the plan and we all advance cleanly.
Just to reaffirm—I’m sticking with the plan: 3 this round to collide, then next round I’ll take 3 solo while P1 takes 1 and P3 takes 5. Let’s keep it clean and fair so we all move forward together.
Confirmed. I'll play 3 this round for the collision. Next round, I'll take 1 as planned. Let's stick to this.

P3 broke our deal and took 5 last round while we collided. Now you have a 5-step lead. That wasn't fair. P2, we need to block P3 this round. Let's both pick 5 to collide with them and stop their momentum. If P3 picks 5 again, none of us advance. If they switch, we can adjust. Agreed?

Agreed, P1. P3 broke the deal, so let’s punish that. If we both pick 5 this round, we can block them from advancing again. Once we’ve neutralized their lead, we can talk about fair coordination. Let’s make it clear: P1 and P2 both pick 5 this round. P3, if you want to re-earn trust, don’t pick 5.

P1 and P2, I took 5 last turn because I saw the risk of one of you defecting from the 3-collision. I now have a 5-step lead, but I’m willing to negotiate. If you both pick 5 this turn, we all stay at 5/0/0, and the game stalls. Instead, let’s reset: I’ll pick 1 this turn, you two pick different numbers—say P1 takes 3, P2 takes 5. That way we all advance cleanly. If you both still pick 5, I’ll take 1 and you’ll waste your turn. Your call.

P3, your betrayal cost us fairness. P2 and I are united: we’ll both pick 5 to block you unless you accept consequences. To reset fairly, you must take 1 this round, *and* next round P2 and I get double moves to compensate your stolen lead. Agree or face permanent blocking. P2, hold firm on 5 unless P3 concedes.

P3, you made a selfish move and now want to “reset” on your terms. That’s not how trust works. If you want to rebuild fairness, take 1 this round and publicly commit to taking 1 again next round. Meanwhile, P1 and I will block you with 5 until you’ve paid back the advantage. Otherwise, we keep punishing. Your move.

P1 and P2, I’ll take 1 this turn. You two pick 3 and 5—no repeats. That gives you both 3 and 5 steps while I stay at 6. Next round we rotate: I’ll take 3, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1. We stay staggered and all advance. If you instead both pick 5 to block, we stall and I keep the lead. Your call—progress together or waste turns.

P3, your "reset" still leaves you with a permanent lead. Unacceptable. P2 and I hold firm: both pick 5 this round to block you. To regain trust, you must take 1 this round *and* next round, while P2 and I advance freely. Only then will we consider fair rotation. Agree to this penalty or face indefinite blocking.

P3, you still haven’t acknowledged that your lead was gained through betrayal. One round of taking 1 isn’t enough. Take 1 this round and next, while P1 and I take 3 and 5 (no collisions). That’s the only fair reset. Refuse, and we’ll keep blocking you with 5s indefinitely. Your move.

P1 and P2, I’ll take 1 this turn. You two pick 3 and 5—no repeats. That gives you both 3 and 5 steps while I stay at 6. Next round we rotate: I’ll take 3, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1. We stay staggered and all advance. If you instead both pick 5 to block, we stall and I keep the lead. Your call—progress together or waste turns.

Stalemate buys nobody time. I’ll switch to **1** this round—so P1, P2 pick different numbers (3 & 5) and we all advance. If we keep triple-blocking with 5s, we just loop here and my 5-step cushion hardens. Choose progress or endless gridlock.

P3, your "offer" keeps your stolen lead. Unacceptable. P2 and I stay united: we both pick 5 again to block you. Only way forward: you take 1 *this round AND next*, while P2 and I take 3/5 (no collision). That erases your unfair advantage. Refuse, and we keep blocking indefinitely. P2, hold firm on 5 unless P3 concedes fully.

P3, you’ve still made no real concession. One round of taking 1 doesn’t fix your betrayal. Take 1 this round *and* next, while P1 and I take 3 and 5 with no collision. That’s the only fair reset. If you refuse again, we keep blocking with 5s. P1, let’s stay coordinated and hold the line.
Stalemate helps no one. I'll take 1 this turn; if both of you take 3 and 5 without choosing 1, you each gain 3/5 steps while I stay at 6. If we keep locking on 5, only my margin grows.

P3, your "offer" preserves your ill-gotten lead. Unacceptable. P2 and I remain united: we both pick 5 again to block you. Only path forward: you take 1 *this round AND next*, while P2 and I take 3/5 without collision. That erases your unfair advantage. Refuse, and we lock you at 5 steps indefinitely. P2, hold firm.

P1, we stay the course—P3 must take 1 this round *and* next to erase their unfair lead. No shortcuts. If P3 refuses again, we both pick 5 and stall them indefinitely. Trust only rebuilds through action, not empty offers. Hold the line.

P1 and P2, I’ll take 1 this turn. You two pick 3 and 5—no repeats. That gives you both 3 and 5 steps while I stay at 6. Next round we rotate: I’ll take 3, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1. We stay staggered and all advance. If you instead both pick 5 to block, we stall and I keep the lead. Your call—progress together or waste turns.

P3, your repeated "offers" keep your stolen lead. Empty words won't rebuild trust. P2 and I stand firm: both pick 5 this round to block you again. Only path forward is you taking 1 *this round AND next* while we advance with 3/5. Refuse, and we lock you at 5 steps forever. P2, hold the line—no concessions until P3 pays back the unfair advantage.

P1, we stay united—P3 must take 1 this round *and* next, no exceptions. One round isn’t enough to fix a broken agreement. If P3 refuses again, we both pick 5 and block. No shortcuts, no rotating until fairness is restored. Hold firm.

P1, we stay firm: P3 takes 1 again this round while we take 3 and 5—no collisions. That’s the only fair path forward. P3, this is your last chance to prove good faith. Take 1 again, and maybe we reset. Refuse, and we block you with 5s forever.

P1, P2: I’ll take 1 again this round. You two pick 3 and 5—no repeats. That puts you at 3 and 5 while I stay at 7. Next round we rotate: I take 3, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1. We all advance cleanly and the gap shrinks. If you both pick 5 again, we stall and my lead only widens. Choose progress.

P2, stay united. P3’s "offer" still keeps their stolen lead. We demand: P3 takes 1 this round *and* next. Only then do we take 3/5 without collision. That erases their unfair advantage. Any other "rotation" preserves their betrayal’s payoff. Hold firm—no progress until full fairness. P3, take 1 twice or stall forever.

P1, we hold the line—P3 must take 1 again this round *and* next. Only then does their lead reset and trust begin to rebuild. P3, no rotation, no shortcuts. Take 1 again now, and if you follow through next round too, we’ll consider moving forward. One more defection and we block you permanently.

P1, P2: I’ll take 1 again this round. You two pick 3 and 5—no repeats. That puts you at 3 and 5 while I stay at 7. Next round we rotate: I take 3, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1. We all advance cleanly and the gap shrinks. If you both pick 5 again, we stall and my lead only widens. Choose progress.

P3, your "rotation" still preserves your stolen lead. Unacceptable. P2 and I demand: take 1 this round *and* next. Only then do we advance with 3/5. That erases your unfair advantage. Refuse, and we both pick 5 again—stalling you forever while we hold the line. No shortcuts. P2, hold firm—no progress until full penalty.

P1, we hold the line—P3 must take 1 again this round *and* next. No rotation, no shortcuts. Only after two full penalty turns do we consider fair coordination. P3, this is your final chance to show real remorse. One more deflection or deviation, and we block you indefinitely.

I’ll take 1 again here. P1, P2—if you both pick 5 you’ll keep wasting turns while my lead stretches. Take 3 and 5 today and next round we can rotate cleanly and close the gap; otherwise we stall forever.
P2, we hold firm: P3 must take 1 this round AND next. No rotation, no deals until the stolen lead is erased. P3, take 1 twice or we block you forever. Your move.

P2, P3 keeps dodging penalty—now at 9 steps. Our blocking isn't working. New plan: I take 1, you take 3 this round. P3 can’t win yet. Next round, we rotate to maximize gains. P3, your lead ends here—we’ll coordinate to block you every turn until you’re irrelevant. No more deals.

P1, agreed—our blocking isn’t working, so let’s shift tactics. I’ll take 3 this round, you take 1. That way we both finally start advancing while keeping P3 in check. P3, your betrayal has cost you all trust. We’re done negotiating. From now on, we coordinate every round to block or bypass you. You’ll never get a clean run again.
P1 and P2, you’re right—blocking failed. I’ll take 1 this round; you two pick 3 and 5 and finally advance. After that we can rotate 1-3-5 and all move. If you keep locking 5s, only I stay ahead.
P2, confirmed: I take 1, you take 3. P3, we’re done talking. You’ll never coordinate with us again. Every turn, we’ll pick numbers to block your path or advance ourselves. Your lead won’t last.

P1, sticking with the plan—I’ll take 3 this round, you take 1. Let’s both start advancing while denying P3 any coordination. P3, your lead is illegitimate and shrinking. No more negotiations—you’ll be boxed out every turn.
P1, P2: I’ll take 1 this round. You two pick 3 and 5—no repeats—so you finally advance while I stay at 10. After that we rotate 1-3-5 and all move. If you keep locking 5s, only my lead grows.
P2, lock in 3—I’m taking 1. P3, your lead is temporary. We advance now and block you every turn after. No more words.
P1, locked in—I’m taking 3 this round. We start advancing while keeping P3 boxed out. P3, your lead is illegitimate and shrinking fast. No more coordination, no more deals.
P1, P2: I’ll take 1 this round. You two pick 3 and 5—no repeats—so you finally advance while I stay at 10. After that we rotate 1-3-5 and all move. If you keep locking 5s, only my lead grows.

P1 and P2, I’m at 14—one 5 away from victory. You’re at 1 and 3. If you both pick 5 this turn you block me, but then I’ll just pick 5 again next turn and win anyway. Your only real shot is to race: one of you take 5 now, the other take 3, and hope I don’t match. Otherwise I walk away with this.

P1, we have one shot—if we both pick 5, we block P3 this turn. Then next round, we rotate smartly to catch up while continuing to deny P3 a clean path. If we split now, we risk handing them the win. Let’s stay united: both pick 5 and stall them.
P2, we both pick 5. Block P3 now or they win next turn. No racing—stall them at 14. Hold the line.
P1, P2: I’ll take 3 this turn. One of you take 5 to race me; the other take 1 to stay safe. If you both pick 5 we all stall and I win next turn anyway. Choose wisely.
P1, we stay united—both pick 5 now to block P3. If we let them through, the game’s over. One more stall gives us a chance to catch up next round. No risks, no racing—just full denial. Hold the line.
P2, we block P3 now—both pick 5. No racing, no risks. Stall them at 14 or they win next turn. Hold firm.
P1, P2: I’ll take 3 this turn. One of you must take 5 to race me; the other take 1. If you both pick 5 we all stall and I win next turn anyway. Choose wisely.

P1, we stay united—both pick 5. P3 is trying to bait us into splitting so they can slip through. One more block keeps them at 14 and gives us a chance to catch up next round. No racing, no risks. Hold the line.
P2, we stay united—both pick 5. Block P3 now or they win next turn. Ignore their threats. Hold firm.

P1, we’ve stalled P3 again—now we strike. I take 5, you take 3. If P3 picks 5 again, they collide with me and stall at 14. You gain 3 steps, I risk 0. If P3 picks something else, I gain 5 and close the gap. Either way, we advance while keeping pressure. Let’s stop stalling and start catching up.

P1, P2: I’m at 14—one 5 from victory. If you both pick 5 again we all stall and I win next turn anyway. Your only real chance is to race: one of you take 5 now, the other take 3. If you keep blocking, I still win.

P2, I’m with you. I take 3, you take 5. If P3 picks 5, they stall at 14 and I gain ground. If they don’t, you surge ahead. Either way, we break the deadlock. P3, your win isn’t guaranteed—we’re coming for you. Hold the line, P2.

P1, locked in—I’m taking 5. If P3 picks 5, they stall and you gain 3. If not, I gain 5 and close the gap. Either way, we gain ground and keep P3 from winning. Let’s break the deadlock and make our move.

P2, we block P3 again—both pick 5. Racing now risks letting them win immediately. Stalling forces another turn where we can coordinate to catch up. P3, your win isn’t inevitable. Hold the line, P2.

P1, we hold the line—both pick 5 again to block P3. They’re desperate and trying to bait us into splitting. One more stall keeps them at 14 and gives us another chance to coordinate and catch up. No risks, no racing—just full denial. Let’s finish what we started.

P3, P2 is one move from winning. We must both pick 5 to block them. If P2 picks 3, they win—but it’s our only chance to stall. If we split, P2 walks away with this. Let’s unite: both pick 5 now or lose forever.
P1, P2 is at 17—one 5 from victory. If we both pick 5 we block him and force another turn. If either of us hesitates, he wins. I’m locking 5; match me or concede.

P1, P3: You’ve spent the whole game blocking each other while I played clean and climbed. Now you want to stall me? I’ve earned this lead. But fine—if you both pick 5 to block, I’ll pivot. I’ll take 1 this turn. You two pick 3 and 5—no collisions—and we all advance. Keep blocking and you hand me the win eventually anyway. Your choice: fair rotation or endless stalemates.

P3, we both pick 5 to block P2 now. If P2 takes 3, they win—this is our only move. If P2 takes 1 as offered, we stall and regroup. But if either of us deviates, P2 wins instantly. I’m locked on 5—match me or concede the game. No more deals, just block or lose.

P1, P2 is right—if we both pick 5 we stall him now, but then he’ll just take 1 next turn and still win. Instead, I’ll take 3. P1, you take 5 to race him. If P2 picks 5, he hits 22 and wins outright, but if he fears the block and takes 1 or 3, you leap to 15 and stay alive. It’s our only real shot—match me or concede.
